intro: Phucagrostis tridentata, commonly known as the three-toothed grass, is a species of flowering plant in the grass family, Poaceae. It is characterized by its slender, tufted growth habit and narrow, linear leaves with a prominent midrib. The plant produces small, spikelet-based inflorescences that bear both male and female flowers, typical of many grasses. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in wet meadows and along stream banks. Phucagrostis tridentata is an important component of wetland ecosystems, providing habitat and food for various invertebrates and birds.
